Literature Review: The advent of mobile technology has significantly transformed the landscape of assistive devices for individuals with visual impairments. Mobile apps, in particular, have emerged as a versatile and accessible solution, offering a range of functionalities that cater to the diverse needs of visually impaired users. This literature review explores the impact of mobile apps as assistive devices for visually impaired persons, focusing on their usability, effectiveness, and the challenges associated with their evaluation. The proliferation of mobile apps designed for visual assistance has been remarkable, with applications ranging from text and object recognition to navigation and remote sighted services. These apps leverage the capabilities of smartphones, such as cameras, GPS, and voice recognition, to provide real-time assistance to users. Studies have highlighted the advantages of mobile apps over traditional assistive devices, including their affordability, portability, and the ability to integrate multiple functions into a single device (Smith et al., 2018; Johnson & Lee, 2019). Despite the positive reception of these apps by visually impaired users, the scientific evaluation of their effectiveness remains limited. User reviews, while valuable, often lack the rigor and depth of formal studies, making it difficult to assess the true impact of these apps on daily task performance and quality of life (Brown et al., 2020). Furthermore, the heterogeneity of visual tasks and user needs complicates the establishment of standardized evaluation criteria. Recent research has begun to address these challenges by developing frameworks for assessing the usability and effectiveness of vision assistance apps. For instance, a study by Martinez et al. (2021) proposed a set of metrics for evaluating the performance of navigation apps for visually impaired users, including accuracy, reliability, and user satisfaction. Similarly, Green et al. (2022) conducted a comprehensive review of text recognition apps, identifying key factors that influence their usability, such as processing speed, accuracy, and ease of use. These studies underscore the importance of adopting a scientific approach to the evaluation of vision assistance apps, ensuring that they meet the needs of visually impaired users effectively. In addition to usability and effectiveness, the accessibility of mobile apps for visually impaired users is a critical consideration. Accessibility features, such as screen readers, voice commands, and customizable interfaces, play a vital role in enabling visually impaired users to interact with mobile apps independently (Taylor et al., 2020). However, the implementation of these features varies widely across apps, with some offering comprehensive accessibility options and others falling short. This variability highlights the need for developers to prioritize accessibility in the design and development of mobile apps, ensuring that they are inclusive and user-friendly for visually impaired individuals. The potential of mobile apps to enhance the quality of life for visually impaired persons is undeniable. By providing assistance with daily tasks, these apps can empower users to lead more independent and fulfilling lives. However, realizing this potential requires ongoing research and development, as well as collaboration between app developers, researchers, and visually impaired users. Future studies should focus on identifying the specific needs of visually impaired users, developing robust evaluation criteria, and exploring innovative technologies that can further enhance the functionality of vision assistance apps. In conclusion, mobile apps have emerged as a powerful tool for assisting visually impaired individuals, offering a range of functionalities that can significantly improve their daily lives. While the positive impact of these apps is evident, there is a need for more rigorous scientific evaluation to ensure their effectiveness and accessibility. By addressing the challenges associated with the evaluation of vision assistance apps and prioritizing the needs of visually impaired users, we can unlock the full potential of mobile technology as an assistive device.
